Opaque, very dark mahogany colour, black appearance.
Rich aroma, roasted, dried dark fruits (prune), molasses, cocoa, coffee notes. Slight alcohol presence.
Intense and complex taste, medium bitter, roasted fruit, brownie, cocoa and coffee. Alcohol present but not prominent. Balanced but noted hoppiness. Fruity bitter finish.
Smooth and creamy palate, slightly oily and sticky. Long aftertaste. 
A great Baltic porter!
Draught at Olhöps Craft Beer House, Valencia. Pitch black - brown head. High malty. Chocolate. Licorice. Acid freshness. Some bitterness. Light alcho burn. Nice.

Noire avec un joli collet brun pâle, elle dégage des arômes de malt rôties, de chocolat et de petits fruits. En bouche, on sent un corps consistant et velouté. Le malt chocolat se fait dabord sentir avec les petits fruits et lalcool. Finale amère et torréfiée qui se dissipe vers le caramel.
Bottle. Black with tan head. Roasty ashy aroma, chocolate. Taste is roasty, ashy, some molasses. Sweet and bitter
Bottle at Craigs. Pours black, nose is chocolate, roast malts, fruity, liquorice, taste is similar, rich.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2017 bottle at home ... deep black ... deep black ... thin tan lacing ... soft dark malts ... dark malts ... dark chocolate ... dark malts ... sweet chocolate ... light sweet malts ... soft chocolate roast ... dark chocolate ... sweet toffee roast ... dark sweet chocolate.. light toffee bitterness. 3.8


Keg at ecbf 2017... Dark black.. Thin tan lacing.. Soft sweet chocolate roast malts nose.. Dark sweet chocolate roast malts.. Heavy sweet chocolate roast malts.. Ruch meaty sweet chocolate roast malts 4.2
Bottle at Craigs. Pours black with a thin tan head. Aromas of liquorice, tar, coffee. Taste is rich dark chocolate, boozy. Finishes rich and sweet, quite hot.

Bottle thanks to Pohjala Chris. Appearance - jet black with a lovely fawn head. Nose - dark chocolate and toffee. Taste - molasses and liquorice well melded. Palate - full bodied with a sweet yet tangy texture and a balanced finish Overall - tasty imperial stout.
Bottle, thanks Raul. Aroma is fudge, roast and smoke. Taste is great too. Sweet, grainy, fudge again, dry

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2016 Bottle at Bier Bier. Black color, brown head. Bittersweet taste with roasted malts, dark fruits, toffee, a bit of hops and chocolate. Bitter finish with toffee, dark fruit, chocolate and coffee. Very nice baltic porter.

On tap at Whats Brewing. A black one, topped by a dense, finger-thick brown head leaving lacings. The aroma has lots of brown sugar tending towards molasses, with coffee and dark bitter chocolate. Its full-bodied, sweet and with some warmth in the back. A nice bitterness, pleasant carbonation and flavors of brown sugar, coffee and dark chocolate. Lasting finish. A sweet, lovely dessert beer that perhaps is a tad on the dark malty side, but its damn fine anyway. 141101

330ml bottle from Panturi, San Sebastían. 28-01-2015.
BBD: 25-11-2015. Batch 033.
In short: tasty dark ale.
Pours black with nice tan head. Coffee, roasty, some tart aromas. Medium body, average carbonation, oily texture. Taste is smooth, roasty, cofffe, some creamy, subtle sweet notes, spicy. Warm aftertaste. Very enjoyable.

Feels bit less choco and coffee than first version, but its definitely here as well very noticeable. Roasted malt background, lovely fruit touch. Feels very smooth with quite dry cocoa finish.
Lovely sweetness with some bitterness. Well balanced and highly enjoyable brew.

33 cl bottle thanks to Ingo! Sampled on January 4, 2015. BB 25 11 15, Batch 033.Black color, dark brown head. Coffee, sweet, light smoked scent, a bit lactic. Sweet, berries, blueberry, coffee taste. Coffee, chocolate, blueberries aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, medium high dry bitterness. Warming alcohol.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2017 Pours almost black with small, tan brown top, has balsamy dark coppery corners. Aroma- intense, darkest malts, a bit too boozy at the beginning, finishes with nice roast presence, some notes of dark chocolate, but sweet and roast combo dominates in a good way. Pleasant malts balance with yeast touch in flavor with enough sweetness left to be imp, moderate dry finish; thick, silky-slick texture- sipping sample. 
PS: I have doubts that this one has been in particular category all the way down to momentum.

330 ml bottle
Black beer with mocha brown head disappearing soon leaving a ring on top of the beer. Aroma has salty licorice, chocolate, roasted malts, pine and some alcohol. Flavor has licorice, roasted malts and sweetness. Palate is quite full with medium carbonation. Finish has medium bitterness and feel of alcohol. After taste has roasted malts, sweet liqueur, salty licorice, coffee and bitterness. Quite sweet. A bit too boozy and too thin, otherwise decent for slow sipping.

Pours black with a brown thick head that comes down. leaving nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is quite thick, full roast and a bit sweet. Its quite simple though, maybe with some chocolate and coffee. It drinks smooth, sweet and velvety, you can feel that 10% only at the end in the aftertaste. Well, I thought wed never see an Öö again (though I do still have one of the originals in bottle), Im glad to be wrong about that. Obsidian black, brief head. Very nice rich roast aroma, hint of dark chocolate cake or espresso. Full palate, but remarkably light, just gentle carbonation to cut through the sweetness. Retronasals packed with fruity esters. Youll notice I added this as an Imperial Stout, as modern Baltic Porters are lagers, so its misleading to enter this as one. (The previous 9.5% one brewed at Genika likewise.) Taste is remarkably non-extreme, which is a good thing. Its all about the roast, nicely burnt, but not ashy, just where I like it. Nice chocolate cakiness, sweetish but a million miles from sticky. If youre like Anna and take small sips, then you will get a waft of alcohol with your sip, but if you take a proper mouthful, theres none to be found. As I said, its remarkably light. And yes, that means that theyre not just hiding the alcohol behing sugars. Hops only have a chance to come out in the finish, a very nice barky dryness that lasts for a while. Of course the burntness is there too, that goes without saying. I have a nasty feeling I could begin sessioning this, but Im not sure how long I could keep it up! Very skillfully brewed impy.
Looking forward to samples of this at Porgu and Drink Baar, and some bottles from Koht...
